title: 108_hr1997
content: The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 2004, also known as "Laci and Conner's Law," amends Title 18 of the United States Code to include a new chapter, "Protection of Unborn Children," which outlines measures for the protection of unborn children. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 2004, known as "Laci and Conner's Law," creates a separate offense for causing harm to a child in utero. The punishment is the same as if the injury or death had occurred to the mother. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 2004, also known as "Laci and Conner's Law," establishes a separate offense for causing harm to an unborn child. The punishment is equivalent to what would be given if the injury or death had happened to the mother. The offense does not require proof of the perpetrator's knowledge of the victim's pregnancy or intent to harm the unborn child. If the conduct results in the intentional killing or attempted killing of the unborn child, the perpetrator will be punished according to other relevant sections of the law.
